newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - May 19.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - May 19.

text.p: These are the Leading stories in the South African press on Monday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
BUSINESS DAY

- JCI Ltd has kick-started talks to merge with UK conglomerate Lonrho Pl# in a deal which would create one of the world's largest mining houses, with a market value of more than $3 billion, industry sources said.
- South Africa granted official recognition on Sunday to Laurent Kabila as president of Zaire, renamed the Democratic Republic of Congo.
- The Infrastructure Finance Corporation, Inca, which provides finance for local authorities, has disbursed the proceeds of 500 million rand it raised through a private placing earlier this year.
- President Nelson Mandela said on Sunday he knew whk ordered the assassination of African National Congress (ANC) councillor Rodney van der Byl in Richmond, KwaZulu Natal.

- The expected walkout by National Party (NP) members following Roelf Meyer's weekend resignation was likely to include ward councillors from four provinceq, some provincial MPs and about 80 percent of Gauteng's youth, party insiders said on Sunday.
BUSINESS REPORT

- South Africa's first black-ovned mining houe, JCI, has started merger talks with British conglomerate Lonrho in a deal that could create one of the world's largest mining companies, a British newspaper reported on Sunday.

- The fallout from Piet den Boer's resignation as chairman last month continues to plague Q Data, the information technology company, whose share fell 26 cents to a seven month low of 7.94 rand on Friday.

- Co-ordinated Network Investments (CNI), the investment company led by management sonsultant Reuel Khoza, has bought a 10 percent stake in unlisted short-term insurer Guardrisk for an undisclosed sum, the companies said at the weekend.
SAKE BEELD
- Namakwa Sands, the world's largest producern of heavy minerals, is concerned about when its second phase will take place.
- The South African financial markets are on the look-out for a positive economic news fo2 the next two weeks after being rocked the previous week.
THE STAR
- At least 200 people have been killed in Kinshasa since Laurent Kabila's forces entered the capital, Zairean Red Cross officials said last night.

- Deputy President Thabo Mbeki led a high-powered delegation of government officials to Lubumbashi on Sunday to meet self-proclaimed new Zairian President Laurent Kabila to seek assurances that he intended respecting democratic rights.

- Soshanguve, north of Pretoria, remained tense on Sunday afternoon with police backed by soldiers maintaining a strong presence in anticipation of a flare-up of taxi-related violence following the burial of two murdered taxi owners.
